{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3571649,"name":"Christopher Larrieu","username":"caparomula","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/43a26b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-28T21:20:05.244Z","cooked":"

I’m curious if anyone has some suggestions on good practice for setting up a pit lan? I’ve been mulling over a configuration that I’ll describe shortly, in order to solve a few problems. The problems are

  1. without a switch, we can only connect one device at a time to the vh109 (because all but one of its ports are in use by vision coprocesors and the rio)
  2. using a simple switch, we’ve encountered weird errors where laptops will oten take quite some time to get an IP address, or if statically configured, will not be able to ping the rio for up to several minutes.
  3. we want to be able to have multiple developers working on code and other tweaks in parallel, but without guaranteed reliable internet, we can’t sync changes via github

So my thought is to

  1. create a linux machine with a cache of the github repo that we can push and pull to/from.
  2. Running on the linux machine is a windows VM with bridged access to the lan, and installed on it are the FRC game tools, REV hardware client, Choreo, and other useful tools.
  3. The linux machine runs a desktop environment and has wpilib dev tools installed, so it can act as a developer station as well.

My main question is: will running a dhcp server on the linux box interfere with the vh109’s dhcp behavior, possibly assigning different IP addresses to robot-local devices?

But more broadly, I’m wondering what sorts of solutions other teams are using to deal with these issues?

Thanks for any tips!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-28T21:20:05.244Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":133.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":497250,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-pit-lan","display_username":"Christopher Larrieu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69322,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-pit-lan/497250/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3571713,"name":"Alex","username":"legoguy1000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/legoguy1000/{size}/256261_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-28T22:08:35.610Z","cooked":"

We use a switch on the robot without an issue. We just use a single laptop for code at events. That way everything is in one place and all changes are accounted for and there’s no chance of the wrong branch/code being deployed. I would not setup a different DHCP server as it will conflict with the radio.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-28T22:08:35.610Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":61.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497250,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-pit-lan","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor & Alumnus"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-pit-lan/497250/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3571807,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-28T23:26:25.809Z","cooked":"

We also stick with 1 laptop for comps, since most work is just tuning and dialing in. The last thing we want to do is make a critical tweak, and then accidentally deploy different code.

In the case we have a bigger feature/rewrite, we have pulled out a different laptop and branched out, but this is rarely something we’re using at that specific competition. So, the need to manage git merges and on-bot networking is pretty minimal.

As far as git goes, you don’t anything especially complicated. You can just run a local Git server and set it as a new Remote. Then just add it to your team’s remote list, and point git operations at this new local server. Github just tends to be a default, and usually goes as the remote name “origin”, but you can have as many of these as you’d like.
https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/git-basics/about-remote-repositories

Thanks for the feedback. Takeaway is (1) simple switch should work fine, (2) keep it as simple as possible.
